awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EarthChem & SESAR - Data Infrastructure for Geochemistry and Earth Science Samples Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth scientists gather a vast amount and diversity of data by collecting specimens of geological materials including rocks, minerals, fossils, sediments, ice, river water or seawater, and analyzing these samples in the laboratory to measure their chemical and physical properties. The data generated by these analyses help scientists understand natural processes of the past, present, and even future Earth systems, and form the basis of new ideas, hypotheses, and discoveries. Thus, it is important that data are preserved and made easily findable and accessible online in a useful format and accompanied by information relevant for other researchers, decision makers, teachers, and the general public. This project continues the operation of two data systems, SESAR (System for Earth Sample Registration) and EarthChem, that provide online open access to information about samples collected as part of Earth and environmental science research, and to data generated when these samples are chemically analyzed in the lab. EarthChem manages and curates hundreds of geochemical datasets contributed by researchers and maintains databases with over 30 million geochemical measurements for more than one million samples. EarthChem will ensure that these data are available to, and consumable by, anyone (educator, student, researcher, industry groups, general public) interested in using them for essentially any purpose, especially research and education in STEM fields. SESAR makes samples discoverable and accessible online, thus allowing more efficient and effective access to sample collections that play a central role in a wide diversity of Earth, environmental, and planetary sciences and may inform critical decisions, laws and policies, and future science. EarthChem and SESAR build important national and international connections among data providers and users that facilitate the availability of information and knowledge to society. 

During the two years of this project, EarthChem and SESAR will provide ongoing data stewardship services for the geochemistry, petrology, and Earth samples communities. EarthChem also will undertake essential developments to modernize and optimize technical implementation, enhance user functions, expand accessible data holdings, and engage with a broad community of users and data facilities to establish best practices and interoperability standards for geochemical data. EarthChem will restructure and reengineer its systems to ensure that its data services scale to evolving community demands and that operations are optimized for efficiency, resilience, and sustainability. New developments will support next generation modes of data-driven research by improving both human and machine-readable interfaces for discovery, access, visualization, and analysis of content in EarthChem data systems. Applications of Machine Learning and other data science approaches will help extract new knowledge from the data collections. SESAR will continue to expand its user community beyond geochemistry and the Earth sciences. In addition, SESAR’s services will move to a new, independent, multi-disciplinary infrastructure for sample registration, an emerging collaborative effort with cyberinfrastructure providers in biology, genomics, and archeology.

This project is jointly funded by the Geoinformatics and the Petrology and Geochemistry programs in the Division of Earth Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
EarthChem is a disciplinary data facility that curates openly accessible digital collections of geochemical and petrological data to maximize their long-term impact for science and society. The focus of Experimental Petrology group's efforts at South Dakota Mines (SDSM&T) is the curation of data derived from petrologic experimental studies. Such studies are conducted at specific conditions on specific compositions. However, to develop predictive models that provide a holistic understanding of natural systems requires a range of experimental conditions and compositions that "covers" a similar range of conditions as natural systems. Therefore, for our discipline to move forward, everyone needs to have access to the same information. That effort is handicapped by the fact that the data from the experiments is organized differently in each publication. The development of an accessible dataset enables FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) data principles which requires that experimental database have required metadata organized in a way yielding useful compilations.

Towards that end, LEPR and traceDs are syntheses of experimental data that simulates natural silicate systems. LEPR focuses on major element phase equilibria and traceDs on trace element partitioning experiments. To date, over 10K phase equilibria experiments have been compiled in LEPR and 5K in traceDs. LEPR and traceDs greatly broaden access to the information used to calibrate geochemical models and help reduce the "black box" aspect of experimental petrology. Both databases are used as a teaching tool in petrology and geochemistry courses at undergraduate and graduate level.

During this grant period we continued to gather transcribe newly published experimental data from the literature and perform quality control. The effort was carried out by the PI Ustunisik and co-PI Nielsen at SDSM&T together with supervised students transcribing data. In addition, we regularly consulted with our VGP community to modify and/or expand the metadata included in the database via regular meetings. Further, this project supported the work of two MS students (Erica Cung and Madison Betts, graduate students at SDSM&T, Advisor PI Ustunisik). Their research centered on understanding how the collective data was configured (e.g., number of experiments, range of compositions, pressure, temperature) and how that influences the outcome of the predictive models that our community produce. These characteristics are different for each mineral (clinopyroxene, garnet, amphibole, orthopyroxene) and for groups of trace elements (REE, HFSE) for each mineral. This results in bias in predictive models and thus bias in the simulations based on partitioning data. Understanding the magnitude and origin of the underlying bias is not possible without a statistical analysis of the data conducted independently of the regression analysis used for predictive modeling. Feedback from the community was gathered at GSA,  AGU, and Goldschmidt to modify the components and style of the database and methods for access. Based on that input, most users stated a preference to access entire mineral datasets - that they would then process using their own approach. Currently, 75% of the downloads comprises the research related needs of the community while 20% of the downloads include teaching-education related activities. In addition to the EarthChem community site, we (PI, co-PI, and graduate students) held webinars to facilitate community access to the databases (https://www.earthchem.org/communities/experimental-petrology/) made several conference presentations,  published results, cooperated with the leadership group for EarthChem, IEDA, and ENKI.

The intellectual impact of this work on the discipline falls into two areas. First, open access to the existing published data on trace element partitioning will allow members of the community to speak the same language and discuss the boundary conditions of "acceptable data". This will enhance the experience of experimentalists who are in the process of starting new projects by allowing them to begin at a much higher level of data access/commonality. Reviewers (for proposals or journal articles) will also be more effective because they can access the same data used by experimentalists and modelers - to test the models, and to evaluate the degree that the investigators pre-selected existing data - or the degree to which their literature search was effective. Further, the datasets provide access for any instructor to teach students how to deal with large datasets, create models, and evaluate their effectiveness. Access to this dataset has already facilitated the development of new teaching modules in upper division and graduate courses. Until now, the threshold to participation was too high for most instructors to engage this subject in a meaningful way. As a part of diversity efforts in geosciences, Ustunisik and Nielsen are part of an organization (Tiospaye) centered at South Dakota that increases access of faculty and students at tribal colleges to technical knowledge and geologic data. The specific role of Ustunisik and Nielsen is to provide an interface between the tribal colleges and SDSM&T with a focus on providing opportunity to Native American students to continue their education at SDSM&T and advising on student transfers.
